title: 104_hr3297
content: There is no relevant information provided in the prev_chunk to summarize the curr_chunk. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to Public Law 95-495 regarding Basswood, Saganaga, Birch, Lac La Croix, and Seagull Lakes in Minnesota. Amendments include specifying counties and removing certain geographical restrictions. Amendments to Public Law 95-495 involve Seagull Lake in Minnesota, removing geographical restrictions in Cook County until January 1, 1999. Amendments to Public Law 95-495 involve changes to guest access and motorized portages in Minnesota lakes. The amendments allow homeowners, resort owners, and their guests to access lakes and permit motorized vehicles for boat transport across specific portages. SEC. 4. Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council established under Public Law 95-495 for managing the wilderness area. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council (referred to as the "Council") is established with 11 members, including the Under Secretary for Natural Resources and Environment, three individuals representing Minnesota state departments, and one individual representing the Minnesota Historical Society. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members, including representatives from various county commissioners, state legislators, and the Native American community. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members, including representatives from county commissioners, state legislators, and the Native American community. The members appointed to the Council serve a two-year term and may continue to serve until their successor is appointed. Members not employed by the Federal Government serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses while conducting Council business. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members, with a quorum of eight members required for meetings. The Council elects a chairperson from among its members, fills vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment, and meets at the call of the chairperson or a majority of members. The Secretary provides staff and technical assistance as needed, and Federal agencies can offer support on a reimbursable basis. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council receives personnel, property, and services on a reimbursable basis to assist in carrying out its duties. The Council is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act, and guidelines ensure that meetings are open to the public. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council holds regular and emergency meetings where interested persons can present statements on agenda items. Public notice of meetings is provided through local newspapers and other means for wide publicity. Meeting minutes are kept to record attendees and discussions. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council keeps detailed meeting records, including attendees, discussions, conclusions, and filed statements. The administrative record, minutes, and related documents are available for public inspection at the Council's offices. Additionally, the Council may consider new information from State or Federal agencies at any time. The Council considers new information from State or Federal agencies and the public when making decisions on management measures. They prepare draft amendments to the management plan to allow for a broad range of sustainable land and water uses. The Council prepares and submits revisions of the management plan to the Secretary for regularly scheduled updates. They consult on environmental impacts of major Federal actions and analyze economic and environmental costs of sustainable practices for the wilderness. The Council conducts public hearings for input on amendments to the management plan and major Federal actions. They also review local, State, and Federal actions for their impact on the region's economic and environmental sustainability, submitting periodic reports to the Secretary. The Council conducts public hearings for input on amendments to the management plan and major Federal actions, reviewing actions for their impact on the region's sustainability. They submit periodic reports to the Secretary and conduct activities required by the Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funding. SEC. 23. MANAGEMENT PLAN: Public Law 95-495 is amended to include a new section for the management plan. The Council conducts public hearings, reviews actions for sustainability impact, submits reports to the Secretary, and receives necessary funding. The Secretary applies this section when amending wilderness management plans or making decisions requiring public involvement. The Secretary receives draft amendments from the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council, reviews public comments, and may submit recommendations for revisions. The Secretary also accepts revised drafts from the Council. The Secretary reviews draft amendments submitted by the Council and may adopt them if they are consistent with laws and in the public interest. If not adopted, the Secretary will make amendments in accordance with the management plan. The management plan board, consisting of three members, is appointed by the Secretary and the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council. The Secretary may request additional lists for appointments. The management plan board, with three members appointed by the Secretary and the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council, includes one member chosen from a list submitted by the other two members. Non-government board members serve without pay and receive travel expenses while on board business. The management plan board, consisting of three members appointed by the Secretary and the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council, reviews and provides comments on revised amendments to the management plan submitted by the Council to the Secretary. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the board. The board reviews and submits amendments to the Secretary for the management plan. If the Secretary does not adopt the amendments, recommendations are made to the Council for further action. No amendments can be implemented until the Secretary complies with the process. If the Council does not submit a revised management plan, the Secretary can make necessary revisions and implement the plan. The Secretary must consult the Council for major Federal actions involving public input. The wilderness management plan can only be changed in accordance with this section.
